title: Data Protection Day 2026: protecting children’s digital privacy
content: European data protection authorities work together to protect your personal data, including children's data, every day. Children are more at risk online than adults because they do not easily recognise dangers. A new hub, Privacy for Kids, will demonstrate how to protect children’s digital privacy.

title: EU and Brazil conclude largest area of free and safe data flows in the world
content: The EU and Brazil have formally confirmed that their levels of data protection are comparable. By recognising this high standard of data protection, businesses, public authorities and researchers can now freely exchange data between the EU and Brazil, boosting digital trade.

title: EU and India conclude ambitious free trade deal
content: The EU and India have concluded a landmark free trade agreement, the largest such deal ever concluded by either side. The agreement creates a free trade zone of 2 billion people, with both sides set to gain economically. It will also strengthen political ties between the world's biggest democracies.

title: January 2026: Cervical cancer awareness month
content: For women in the EU aged 15-44, cervical cancer is the second most common form of cancer (after breast cancer). This cervical cancer awareness month, find out more about what the EU is doing to prevent cervical cancer and improve cancer care.

title: EU will continue to stand up for itself against any form of coercion
content: At an informal meeting, EU leaders reaffirmed that the EU will defend itself and its member states, citizens and companies. The EU has the power and the tools, and will use them if and when necessary.

title: EU study shows rooftop solar power could meet 40% of EU’s long-term electricity demand
content: A new EU-wide analysis shows that rooftop solar photovoltaics could supply around 40% of Europe’s electricity by 2050. According to the study, the rooftops of EU’s 271 million buildings could host sufficient solar photovoltaic capacity to generate around 2,750 terawatt-hours of electricity per year.
